div.p: THE VVELL OF WISEDOME, CONTEINING CHIEFE AND CHOSEN ſayinges vvhich may leade all men to perfect and true vviſedome, as vvell to Godvvard as to the vvorlde: GATHERED OVT OF THE FIVE bookes of the olde Teſtament, eſpecially belonging to VViſedome, that is to ſay, the Prouerbes of Salomon, Eccleſiaſtes, Canticum, Sapientia and Eccleſiaſticus, and beſtowed in vſuall common places in order of A. B. C. By T. C.
div.q: PROVERBES 2. It is the Lorde that geueth wiſedome, out of his mouth commeth knowledge and vnderſtanding.

div.head: TO THE WORSHIPFVL M. NEVVELL SOTHERTON, CLERKE OF THEXTRETES OF the Queenes Maieſties Court of Exchequer: grace, mercy and peace from God the Father, and from the Lord Ieſus Chriſt.
div.p:
AMong all the giftes that euer God beſtovved on mā kind, vviſedom excelleth: vvhich is not only by King Salomon and his vvritinges ſincerely vvitneſſed, but alſo by good gouernment & orders of diuers Princes, rulers, counſellers, and ſtates of common vvelths, from time to time in euery age confirmed. And although the bookes of the olde Teſtament named Sapientiall, ſet forth directly neither lavv, propheſie nor hiſtorie, yet doe they plainly expreſſe matters of vviſedom, and arguments incident thereunto. And vvhen as for my ovvne inſtruction I had of late collected
the chiefeſt ſayings to the order of common places, I did conſider that they published might ſomevvhat profit others, being applied to proper intents and purpoſes. And thereupon vnderſtanding of your ſpeciall zeale to good learning, and ſingular imitation of the fruites conteined in the ſaid bookes, haue thought good to preſent theſe my labours vnto you as a patrone conuenient for ſuch a vvorke. For myne ovvne parte I acknovvledge that by reading the bookes aforeſayd, I haue obtained more vnderſtanding euen in vvorldly affayres, then my yong yeres by experiēce haue taught me, or my trauels at Oxford in the ſtudy of profane authors directed me. And no maruell, for vvho in vviſedom either is or hath ben at any tyme like vnto Salomon, is it not vvritten in the third of Kings & third chapter, that vpon prayer made by Salomon for an vnderſtanding heart, God ſayd vnto him, becauſe thou hast asked this thing, and hast not asked long life, neither riches, nor the liues of thine enemies:
See I haue done according to thy petition, and beholde I haue geuen thee a vviſe and an vnderſtanding heart, ſo that there vvas none like thee before thee, neither after thee shall any ariſe like vnto thee. And againe in the tenth chapter of the ſame booke: that the Queene of Saba came to Ieruſalem from the vttermoſt coaſtes of the land to heare and ſee the vviſedom of Salomon, and in ſumme that king Salomō exceded all the Kings of the earth in riches and vviſedome, that all the vvorld reſorted to Salomon to heare his vviſedome vvhich God had put in his heart. This being true of vvhom then may vve better learne vviſedom then of the vviſest? VVhoſe ſayinges becauſe they be alſo of the holy ſcripture, ought vvith more heede to be marked, and vvill doubtles in euery good mans heart be the deeper imprinted. For the ſayinges of the vviſe and vnvviſe are not vvith vviſe men of like authoritie, neither are the ſayinges of the ſacred ſcriptures and of other vvriters
likevviſe to be valued. But other mens ſayings ſo farre allovved as by ſcripture they may be confirmed. Then although Thales, Solon, Chilo, Pitachus, Bias, Cleobulus, Periander, vvhich vvere named the ſeuen vviſe men of Grecia: If Pythagoras, Socrates, Plato, Ariſtotle, Theophraſtus and many moe, both vviſe and learned Philoſophers haue vttered ſundry ſayinges and ſentences inducing to vertue and vviſedom. Yet are not their ſayings likevviſe to be regarded as the ſayings of Salomon or Ieſus Syrach, nay in reſpect of Salomon they vvere all but fooles: neither vvas their vviſedom true and perfect vviſedom, becauſe they vvanted the feare & right knovvledge of God. VVherefore ſuch learned men as haue tranſlated their ſayinges into English, and ſet them forth togither vvith the ſayings of Salomon, and other out of the holy ſcripture, as they are to be prayſed for their diligence, vvilling to profit others that can not vnderstande the Latine tongue, ſo are they not to be prayſed
for mingling Sacra prophanis, vvhether it be touching doctrine, or conuerſation. Notvvithstanding I graunt many of their ſayings to be good, and to leade a man to vviſedom, neyther doth the one take avvay the other, but ought as they be in deed ſo to be eſtemed. Therfore to cōclude, although it vvell appeare that all theſe ſayings are and haue bene knovvne to you longe ſince, for that you haue traueled for triall of doctrine, and quieting of your conſcience thorough out the holy Byble ſufficiently, yet may theſe common places, (vvhich is the commoditie of abridgmēts) bring you in mind of many thinges red before. But they are not gathered for your better inſtruction or others, vvhich be vviſe and learned, and able of them ſelues to gather much better & in better order, but for the rude and ignorant, vvho though they can read, yet haue not iudgement to diſcerne and to diſſeuer ſentences. And as touching the name geuen to the booke, it is taken out of the eighteene chapter of the
Prouerbes, vvhere I reade it vſed in like ſenſe, videlicet, the vvords of the vviſe mans mouth are like a full ſtreame. And againe in the firſt of Eccleſiaſticus, Gods vvorde in the height is the vvell of vviſedom. God graunt therefore that out of this vvell vve may dravv plentifully both true vviſedome to guide vs in doing, and true doctrine to direct vs in beleuing, that in the end vve may fully taſt of him vvhich geueth all true vviſdom, vvhich is the very fountaine of life Chriſt Ieſus, and here moſt hartely I deſire you to accept this dedication in good part as a perfect ſignification of beneuolence in him that vvisheth you increaſe of felicitie, and all vertuous actions thorough the benefite and rule of vviſedom. From Oriall college in Oxford, the xx. of Auguſt. anno 1573.

div.head: THE PREFACE to the Reader.
div.p:
I might ſeeme (gentle reader) to haue attempted a needeles work in ſetting forth ſentences of Scripture, which (God be thā ked) through daily reading and preaching are nowe rife in euery mans mouth: but the cauſes mouing me thereto, are before alleaged in mine epiſtle. And in deede I haue ſet forth nothing but Scripture: gathering the places as the chapters and bookes are placed in the Bible: and in the ſame tranſlation which is commonly vſed and by authoritie approued. Which places being well conſidered, may geue vs to vnderſtand, that God of his goodnes, hath layd before vs through his diuine wiſedom, not only our dutie towarde him, and right beleefe in him: but alſo in ſome part or other of the ſcripture, how we ought to deale
in worldely affayres, yea more then that, what dyet we ought to keepe in eating & drinking, yea what maners we ought to vſe both at the table and els where. So that the Bible may ſeme to containe all thinges neceſſary to be knowen of vs any maner of way. But may we not learne wiſedome otherwhere then in the ſcripture? yes truly, yet ſo as S. Auguſt. writeth de doct. Chriſt. cap. vlt. Quicquid homo extra didicerit, ſi noxium eſt, hic damnatur: ſi vtile eſt, hic inuenitur: & quum ibi quiſque inuenerit omnia, quae vtiliter alibi didicit, multo abundantius ibi inueniet ea, quae nuſquam aliter inuenire potuit. And certes, in the reading of Salomon and Ieſus Syrach, I founde diuers ſayinges, which be alſo red in prophane writers, as in the Prou. 22.Prou. 22. Teach a childe in his youth what way he ſhould goe, &c. The like is in the Poet Horace. Quo ſemel eſt imbuta recens ſeruabit odorem teſta diu. In Eccle. What manner of man the ruler of theEccle. 10.
citie is, ſuch are they that dwel therein alſo. The ſame is alleaged by Cicero out of Plato. Quales in republica principes, tales reliqui ſolent eſſe ciues. And in Eccle. 12. In heauines & trouble a man ſhall know his friende. The ſame is vſed of Cicero in Lelio. Amicus certus in re incerta cernitur. Likewiſe may be ſayde of a greate number moe. Whereby are vnderſtande that the ſame God which gaue wiſedome abundantly vnto Salomon, hath likewiſe powred ſome ſparkes of wiſdom into heathen mens hearts, whereunto if they had ioyned true knowledge of God, then had they bene wiſe men in deede. Yet are not they ſo greatly to be blamed as thoſe Chriſtians, at leaſt wiſe by name, (though in deede much worſe then heathen or Infidels) which reading and hearing the true wiſedome of God, doe vtter in doing moſt deuiliſh policie. Nay many engliſhAnglus Italiatus. men being Italianate, doe proue the prouerbe true to be deuils incarnate,
hauing more delite in the prince of darkenes, ſet forth by Machiauell,Machiauel. or his diſcourſe leading headlong to hell, then in Gods word, which is the well of wiſedome, or the euerlaſting cōmaundementes, which are the entrance vnto it. So that a man may ſee great difference in wiſedome, which alſo is noted in Eccleſiaſticus 19. afterEccleſiaſticus 19. this maner: The feare of God is all vviſedome, and he that is a rightwiſe man keepeth the law. As for the doctrine of wickedneſſe, it is no wiſedom: and the prudence of ſinners is no good vnderſtanding: it is but wickednes, and abomination, & blaſpheming of wiſedom, which alſo is written of the heathen Philoſopher Plato: Scientia quae eſt remota à iuſticia, calliditas potius quam ſapientia eſt appellanda. Yet nowe a dayes, vice beareth the name of vertue. Subtiltie I ſay, hath the countenance of wiſedom, yea among thoſe which (as men ſay) be no ſmall fooles. But God in the ende, as
S. Paule witneſſeth, Corin. 1. will deſtroyCorin. 1. the wiſedom of the wiſe, and wil caſt away the vnderſtanding of the prudent. For the fooliſhnes of God is wiſer then men: and the weakeneſſe of God is ſtronger then men. God graunt that the wiſe of the world, may in the ende be as the fooliſh whom God hath choſen. Yea as Socrates & Plato with ſome other of the beſt and wiſeſt Philoſophers, whom notwithſtanding their miſ beleefe, God of his infinite mercy hath receaued to grace, as Iuſtine the Martyr, S. Auguſtine and other haue iudged.

q.p: IF any of you lacke wiſedom, let him aſke of God which geueth to all men indifferently, and caſteth no man in the teeth: and it ſhall be geuen him.

p.hi: The prayer of Salomon to obtayne wiſedom.

q.p: O God of my fathers, and Lord of mercies, thou that haſt made all thinges with thy word, and ordayned man thorough thy wiſedom, that he ſhoulde haue dominion ouer the creatures which thou haſt made: that he ſhould order the world according to equitie and righteouſnes, and execute iudgement with a true heart: geue me wiſedome which is euer about thy ſeate, and put me not out from among thy children: for I thy ſeruaunt and ſonne of thy handmaiden, am a feeble perſon, of a ſhort time, and too yong to the vnderſtanding of iudgement & the lawes. And though a man be neuer ſo perfect among the children of men, yet if thy wiſedome be not with him, he ſhall be nothing regarded. O ſend her out of thy holy heauens, and from the throne of thy Maieſtie, that ſhe may be with me and labour with me: that I may knowe what is acceptable in thy ſight, for ſhe knoweth & vnderſtandeth all thinges: and ſhe ſhall leade me ſoberly in my workes, and preſerue me in her power, ſo ſhall my workes be acceptable.

div.head: ADVERSITIE AND proſperitie.
div.p: Eccleſiaſtes 7. 16. VSe well the time of proſperitie, and remember the time of misfortune: for God maketh the one by the other, ſo that a man can finde nothing elſe.

Eccleſiaſticus 2. 4. 5. Whatſoeuer hapneth vnto thee, receaue it: ſuffer in heauines and be patient in thy trouble. for like as gold and ſiluer are tried in the fire, euen ſo are acceptable men in the fornace of aduerſitie. Beleue in God, and he ſhall helpe thee: order thy way aright and put thy truſt in him: hold faſt his feare and grow therein.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 11. Laugh no man to ſcorne in the heauines of his ſoule: for god (which ſeeth all things) is he that can bring downe, and ſet vppe againe.
Eccleſiaſticus 11. 14. Proſperitie and aduerſitie, life & death, pouertie and riches, come all of the Lord.
Eccleſiaſticus 11. 25. When thou art in welfare, forget not aduerſitie: and when it goeth not well with thee, haue a good hope that it ſhal be better.

Eccleſiaſticus 12. 8. 9. In proſperitie a friend ſhall not be knowen: and in aduerſitie an enemie ſhall not be hidd, for when a man is in welth it greeueth
his enemies: but in heauines and trouble a man ſhall know his friend.

div.head: Aduoutrie.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus. 23. 18. 19. A Man that breaketh wedlocke and regardeth not his ſoule, but ſayeth: Tuſh, who ſeeth me? I am compaſſed about with darkeneſſe, the walls couer me; no body ſeeth me: whom neede I to feare? The higheſt will not remember my ſinnes: He vnderſtandeth not that his eyes ſee all thinges, for all ſuch feare of men driueth away the feare of God from him, for he feareth onely the eyes of men, and conſidereth not that the eyes of the Lorde are clearer then the Sunne, beholding all the waies of men, and the ground of the deepe, and loking euen to mens heartes in ſecrete places.

Prou. 2. 16. 17. 18. 19. An aduouterous woman geueth ſweete wordes, forſaketh the huſband of her youth and forgetteth the countenance of her god, for her houſe is inclined vnto death, and her paths vnto hel, all they that goe in vnto her come not againe, neither take they holde of the way of life.

Prou. 5. 3. 4 5. Apply not thou thy ſelfe to the deceitfulnes of a woman, for the lippes of an harlot
are a dropping hony combe, and her throte is more gliſtering then oyle, but at the laſt ſhe is as bitter as wormewod, and her tongue as ſharpe as a two edged ſworde, her feete goe downe vnto death, and her ſtepps perſe thorough vnto hell.
Prou. 6. 32. 33. Whoſo committeth aduoutry with a woman he is a foole: and bringeth his life to deſtruction: he getteth him ſelfe alſo ſhame and diſhonor, ſuch as ſhall neuer be put out.
Prou. 22. 14. The mouth of an harlot is a deepe pitt. wherein he falleth that the Lord is angry withall.
Prou. 23. 27. 28. An whore is a deepe graue, and an harlot is a narrow pit: ſhe lurketh like a theefe and bringeth vnto her ſuch men as be full of vice.

Eccleſiaſticus 9. 4. 5. 6 Looke not vppon a woman that is deſirous of many men, leſt thou fall into her ſnares, caſt not thy mind vpon harlots in any maner of thinge, leſt thou deſtroy both thy ſelfe and thine heritage.

Eccleſiaſticus 9. 11. Sit not with an other mans wife by any meanes, lye not with her vpon the bedde: make no wordes with her at the wine, leſt thine heart conſent vnto her, and thou with thy bloud fall into deſtruction.

Eccleſiaſticus 9. 9. An aduouterous woman ſhall be troden
vnder foote as mire, of euery one that goeth by the way.
Eccleſiaſticus 26. 9. The whoredome of a woman may be knowen in the pride of her eies & eye lidds.

div.head: Age.
div.p: Pro. 16. 31. AGe is a crowne of worſhip if it be founde in the way of righteouſnes.
Pro. 20. 29. The ſtrength of yonge men is their worſhip, and a gray head is an honour vnto the aged.

Eccleſiaſtes 11. 9. Be glad (O thou yōg man) in thy youth, and lett thy heart be merry in thy yonge dayes: followe the wayes of thyne owne heart and the luſt of thyne eyes, but be thou ſure that God ſhall bring thee into iudgement for all theſe thinges.

VViſ. 4. 8. 9 Age is an honorable thing: neuertheles it ſtandeth not in the length of time, nor in the multitude of yeares: but a mans wiſedom is the gray heare, and an vndefiled life is the olde age.
Eccleſiaſticus. 8. 6. Thinke ſcorne of no man in his old age, for we waxe olde alſo.

Eccleſiaſticus 8. 9. Goe not from the doctrine of thyne elders: for they haue learned it of their fathers, for of them thou ſhalt learne vnderſtanding, ſo that thou mayſt make anſwere
in the time of neede.
Eccleſiaſticus 25. 3. 4. 5. 6. If thou haſt gathered nothinge in thy youth, what wilt thou finde then in thine age.

O how pleaſant a thing is it when gray headed men are diſcreete, and when the elders can geue good counſayle. O how comly a thing is wiſedom vnto aged men: yea vnderſtanding and counſayle is a glorious thing. The crowne of olde men is to haue much experience: and the feare of God is their worſhip.

div.head: Almes.
div.p: Prou. 3. 27. 28. GEue vnto ye poore, ſo ſhal thy barnesProu. 3. 10. be filled wt plenteouſnes, & thy preſſes ſhal flow ouer with ſweete wine. Withdrawe no good thinge from them that haue need ſo long as thine hand is able to do it. Say not vnto thy neighbour, go thy way and come again, to morow wil I geue thee, whereas thou haſt nowe to geue him.
Prou. 14. 31 He that doth a pooreman wronge blaſphemeth his maker: but whoſo hath pity on the poore doth honour vnto God.
Prou. 17. 5. Whoſo laugheth the poore to ſcorne blaſphemeth his maker: and he that is glad of an other mans hurt ſhall not be vnpuniſhed.

Eccleſiaſticus 4. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. My ſonne, defraude not the poore of his almes, and turne not away thyne eyes from him that hath neede. Deſpiſe not an hungry ſoule, and defie not the poore in his neceſſitie, greeue not the heart of him that is helpeleſſe: and withdraw not thy gift from the needefull. Refuſe not the prayer of one that is in trouble: turne not away thy face from the needy: caſt not thyne eyes aſide from the poore for any euill will, that thou geue him none occaſiō to ſpeak euil of thee: for if he complayne of thee in the bitternes of his ſoule, his prayer ſhall be heard, euen he that made him ſhall heare him.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 10. Be not faynt hearted when thou makeſt thy prayer, neither ſlacke in geuing of almes. Reach thyne hand vnto the poore that God may bleſſe thee with plenteouſnes.
Eccleſiaſticus 29. 12. 13. 14. Lay vp thyne almes in the hand of the poore, and it ſhall keepe thee from all euill.

A mans almes is a purſe with him and ſhall keepe a mans fauour as the apple of an eye, and afterward ſhall it ariſe, and pay euery man his rewarde vpon his head, It ſhal fight for thee agaynſt thy enemies better then the ſheelde of a gyant or ſpeare of the mighty.

div.head: Ambition.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 7. 4. LAbour not vnto man for any Lordeſhip, neyther vnto the king for the ſeat of honour.

6. Make no labour to be made a Iudge, except it were ſo, that thou couldeſt mightely put downe wickednes, for if thou ſhouldeſt ſtand in awe of the preſence of the mighty, thou ſhouldeſt fayle in geuing ſentence.

Eccleſiaſticus 32. 1. 2. 3. 4. If thou be made a ruler, pride not thy ſelf therein, but be thou as one of the people. Take diligent care for them and looke well thereto: and when thou haſt done all thy duty, ſet thee downe that thou mayſt be merry with them, & receaue a crowne of honour, talke wiſely and honeſtly, for wiſedom becommeth thee full well. Speake not where there is no audience, and powre not forth wiſedom out of time.

div.head: Battayle.
div.p: Prou. 24. 5. 6. A Wiſe man is euer ſtrong: yea a man of vnderſtāding increaſeth of ſtrēgth for with diſcretion muſt warres be taken in hand, and where as many are that can geue good counſayle, there is ye victory.

Eccleſiaſti. 26. 29. There be two thinges that greeue my
heart, and the third is a diſpleaſure come vpon me. When an expert man of warre ſuffereth ſcarſeneſſe and pouertie, when men of vnderſtanding and wiſedom are not ſet by, and when one departeth from righteouſnes vnto ſinne.

div.head: Bevvtie.
div.p: Pro. 31. 30. AS for fauour it is deceitfull, & bewtie is a vayne thing.
Eccleſiaſticus 9. 5. 8. Beholde not a mayden that thou be not hurt in her bewtie.
Turne away thy face from a bewtifull woman, and looke not vpon the faireneſſe of other: many a man hath periſhed thorough the bewtie of women, for thorough it the deſire is kindled as it were a fire.
10. Many a man wondering at the bewtie of a ſtraung woman, hath bene caſt out: for her wordes kindle as a fire.
Eccleſiaſticus 11. 2. Commend not thou a man in his bewty, neither deſpiſe a man in his vtter appearaunce.
Eccleſiaſticus 42. 12. 13. Behold not euery bodies bewtie, & haue not to much dwelling among women. For like as the worme and moth commeth out of the clothing, ſo doth wickedneſſe come of women.

div.head: Boaſting and preſumption.
div.p: Pro. 27. 1. MAke not thy boaſt of to morow, for thou knoweſt not what may happen to day.

Eccleſiaſticus 5. 2. 3. Follow not the luſt of thine owne heart in thy ſtrength, and ſay not: tuſh, how haue I had ſtrength, or who wil bring me vnder becauſe of my workes, for doubtles God ſhall aduenge it.

Eccleſiaſticus 5. 5. 6. 7 Becauſe thy ſinne is forgeuen thee be not therefore without feare, neither heape one ſinne vpon an other, & ſay not: tuſh the mercy of the Lord is great, he ſhall forgeue me my ſinnes be they neuer ſo many, for like as he is mercifull, ſo goeth wrath from him alſo, & his indignation commeth down vpon ſinners. Make no tarying to turne vnto the lord, & put not of from day to day: for ſodenly ſhall his wrath come, & in the time of vengeaunce he ſhall deſtroy thee.

div.head: City.
div.p: Pro. 11. 10. WHen the iuſt are in welth the citie proſpereth: but when the vngodly haue the rule it decayeth.
Prou. 29. 8. Wicked people bring a citye in decay: but wiſe men ſet it vp againe.

Eccleſiaſticus 10. 1. When they that be in authoritie are
men of vnderſtanding, there the citie proſpereth.

div.head: Company.
div.p: Prou. 1. 10. 11. 15. 16. MY ſonne conſent not vnto ſinners if they entiſe thee, and ſay come with vs: we will lay waite for bloud and lurke priuily for the innocent without a cauſe. My ſonne walke not with them, refraine thy foote from their way: for their feete runne to euill: and are haſty to ſhedde bloud.
Prou. 13. 20 He that goeth in the company of wiſe men ſhall be wiſe: but whoſo is a companion of fooles ſhall be hurt.

Prou. 23. 20. 21. Keepe not company with wine bibbers and riotous eaters of fleſh: for ſuch as be drunkards and riotous ſhall come to pouertie, and he that is geuen to much ſleepe ſhal goe with a ragged coate.

Eccleſiaſticus 6. 35. 36. 37. Stand with the multitude of ſuch elders as haue vnderſtanding, and conſent vnto their wiſedom with thyne heart, that thou mayſt heare all godly ſermons, and that the worthy ſentences eſcape thee not. And if thou ſeeſt a man of diſcreete vnderſtanding, get thee ſoone vnto him, and let thy foote treade vpon the ſtepps of his doores.

Eccleſiaſticus 8. 8. Deſpiſe not the ſermons of ſuch elders as haue vnderſtanding, but acquaint thy ſelfe with the wiſe ſentences of them: for of them thou ſhalt learne wiſedom, and the doctine of vnderſtanding, and howe to ſerue great men without complaint.
Eccleſiaſticus 13. 1. Whoſo toucheth pitch ſhalbe filed withall: and he that is familiar with the proude ſhall cloth him ſelfe with pride.
2. He taketh a burthen vppon him that accompanieth a more honorable man then him ſelfe. Therefore keepe no familiaritie with one that is richer then thy ſelfe.

div.head: Communication or talke.
div.p: Prou. 13. 3. HE that keepeth his mouth, keepeth his life: but whoſo openeth his lippes to euill deſtroyeth him ſelfe.

Prou. 15. 1. 2. A ſofte anſwere putteth downe diſpleaſure: but froward wordes prouoke vnto anger. The tongue of ſuch as be wiſe vſeth knowledge aright, as for a fooliſh mouth it bableth out nothing but fooliſhnes.
Prou. 16. 26 A wiſe heart ordereth his mouth wiſely, and amendeth the doctrine in his lippes.
Prou. 16. 28 A froward body cauſeth ſtryfe: and he that is a blabbe of his tongue maketh diuiſion among Princes.

Pro. 17. 27. A wiſe man vſeth a few words, and he is a man of vnderſtanding that maketh much of his ſpirite: Yea a very foole when he holdeth his tongue is counted wiſe: & to haue vnderſtanding when he ſhutteth his lippes.
Prou. 18. 4. The wordes of a wiſe mans mouth are like deepe waters, and the well of wiſedom is like a full ſtreame.
Prou. 21. 23 Whoſo kepeth his mouth & his tongue, the ſame keepeth his ſoule from troubles.
Pro. 29. 20. If thou ſeeſt a man that is haſty to ſpeak vnaduiſed, thou mayſt truſt a foole more then him.

Eccleſiaſtes 5. 2. Eccleſiaſticus 4. 24. Where many words are, there men may heare fooles. In the tongue is wiſedom knowen, ſo is vnderſtanding knowledge and learning in the talking of the wiſe, and ſtedfaſt, and in the workes of righteouſnes.
Eccleſiaſticus 5. 12. Eccleſiaſticus 5. 14. Be ſwift to heare, but ſlowe and patient in geuing anſwere.
Honour and worſhip is in a mans wiſe talking, but the tongue of the vndiſcreete is his owne deſtruction.
Eccleſiaſticus 6. 5. A ſweete word multiplieth friendes, and pacifieth them that be at variance, & a thākful tongue wil be plenteous in a good man.

Eccleſiaſticus 20. 7. A wiſe man will hold his tongue till he ſee opportunitie, but a wanton and vndiſcrete
body ſhall regard no time.
Eccleſiaſticus 21. 16. The talk of a foole is like an heauy burthen by the way: but to heare a wiſe man ſpeake it is a pleaſure.
Eccleſiaſticus 27. 12. If thou be among the vndiſcrete, keepe thy wordes vntill a conuenient time, but among ſuch as be wiſe ſpeake on hardly.

div.head: Conſtancy.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 5. 9. 10. BE not caried about with euery winde, and go not into euery way, for ſo doth the ſinner that hath a double tongue. Stand faſt in the way of the Lord, be ſtedfaſt in thy vnderſtanding, abide by the word & follow the word of peace & righteouſnes.

div.head: Correction.
div.p: Prou. 3. 11. 12. MY ſonne deſpiſe not the chaſtening of the lord: neither faint when thou art rebuked of him. For whom the Lord loueth, him he chaſteneth, & yet deliteth in him euen as a father in his own ſōne.
Prou. 10. 17 To take heede vnto the chaſtening of nurtour is the way of life: but he that refuſeth to be refourmed deceiueth him ſelfe.
Pro. 12. 1. Whoſo loueth wiſedom will be content to be refourmed: but he that hateth to be reproued is a foole.
Prou. 13. 18 He that thinketh ſcorne to be refourmed commeth to pouertie and ſhame: but whoſo regardeth correction ſhall come to honour.
Prou. 13. 24 He that ſpareth ye rod hareth his ſonne: but whoſo loueth him chaſteneth him betimes.
Prou. 15. 5. A foole deſpiſeth his fathers correction, but he that taketh heede when he is reproued ſhall haue the more vnderſtanding.
Prou. 15. 31 The eare that harkeneth to the reformation of life, ſhall dwel among the wiſe.
Prou. 15. 32 He that refuſeth to be refourmed, deſpiſeth his owne ſoule: but he that ſubmitteth him ſelfe to correction is wiſe.
Pro. 17. 10. One reprofe onely doth more good to him that hath vnderſtanding then a hundred ſtripes vnto a foole.
Pro. 19. 29. Puniſhments are ordayned for the ſcornfull, and ſtripes for fooles backes.
Prou. 23. 13. 14. Withhold not correction from the child, for if thou beateſt him with the rodde, he ſhall not dye therof. If thou ſmite him with the rodde thou ſhalt deliuer his ſoule from hell.
Pro. 29. 15. The rodde and correction miniſter wiſedome, but if a childe be not looked vnto, he bringeth his mother to ſhame.

Pro. 29. 17 Nurtour thy ſonne with correction, and
thou ſhalt be at reſt: yea he ſhall doe thee good at thyne heart.
Eccleſiaſticus 10. 26. He that is wiſe and well nurtoured will not grudge when he is refourmed, and an ignorant body ſhall not come to honour.

div.head: Countenaunce.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 13. 26. 27. THe heart of a man chaungeth his countenaunce, whether it be in good or euill. A cheerefull countenaunce is a token of a good heart, for elſe it is an hard thing to know the thought.
Eccleſiaſticus 19. 27. 28. One that hath vnderſtanding may be perceaued by the loke of his countenaunce.
A mans garment, laughter, and going, declareth what he is.

div.head: Counſayle and counſellers.
div.p: Prou. 11. 14 WHere no good counſayle is, ther the people decay: but where as many are that can geue good counſayle, there is wealth.
Pro. 12. 15. Looke what a foole taketh in hande, he thinketh it well done: but he that is wiſe will be counſayled.
Pro. 15. 22. Vnaduiſed thoughts ſhal come to nought but where as men are that can geue good counſayle, there is ſtedfaſtnes.
Pro. 15. 23. A ioyfull thing is it to a man when his counſayle is followed, and very pleaſant is a word ſpoken in due ſeaſon.
Prou. 16. 21 Whoſo hath a wiſe vnderſtanding ſhall be called to counſayle.
Pro. 20. 18. Wiſe counſayle in the heart of man is like a water in the deepe of the earth, and a man that hath vnderſtanding bringeth it forth.
Prou. 20. 18 Thorough counſayle the thinges that men deuiſe goe forward, and with diſcretion ought warres to be taken in hand.
Prou. 21. 5. The deuiſes of one that is diligent bring plenteouſneſſe: but he that is vnaduiſed commeth vnto pouertie.
Pro. 21. 30. There is no wiſedom, there is no vnderſtanding, there is no counſel againſt ye lord.
Prou. 28. 2. Becauſe of ſinn the land doth oft change her prince: but thorough men of vnderſtanding and wiſedom a realme endureth long.
Eccleſiaſticus 8. 17. 18 Take no counſell at fooles, for they loue nothing but the things that pleaſe them ſelues. Make no counſel before a ſtranger, for thou canſt not tell what will come of it.

Eccleſiaſticus 37. 7. 8. 9. 10. 11. 12. 13. Seeke no counſell at thy kinſman, and hide thy counſell from ſuch as bore thee no good will. Euery counſeler bringeth forth his counſell, neuertheles there is ſome that
counſeleth but for his owne profit. Beware of the counſeler and be aduiſed afore where to thou wilt vſe him, for he will counſell for him ſelfe, leſt he caſt the lot vpon thee and ſay vnto thee: thy way and purpoſe is good: and afterward he ſtand againſt thee & looke what ſhall become of thee. Aſke no counſel at him that ſuſpecteth thee for an enemie, and hide thy counſel from ſuch as hate thee. Aſke no counſell at a woman concerning the thinges that ſhe longeth for: nor at a fearefull and fainthearted body, in matters of warre: nor at a marchaunt how deare he will cheape thy wares toward his: or at a bier of ſelling: or at an enuious man of thankes geuing: or at the vnmercifull of louing kindnes: or at an vnhoneſt man of honeſtie: or at the ſlouthful of working: or at an hireling which hath no houſe or profit of welth. Take no ſuch folkes to counſell: but be diligent to ſeke counſel at a vertuous man that feareth god: ſuch one as thou knoweſt to be a keeper of the commaundementes, which hath a mind after thine owne mind, & is ſory for thee when thou ſtumbleſt. And holde thy counſell faſt in thine heart, for there is no man more faithfull to kepe it then thou thy ſelfe.

Eccleſiaſticus 19. 8. 9. Shew thy ſecretes neither to friend nor foe, and if thou haſt offended tel it not, for he ſhall harken vnto thee, and when he findeth opportunitie, he ſhall hate thee, and ſo ſhall he be alway about thee.
Eccleſiaſticus 37. 16. Before all thy workes aſke counſayle firſt: and or euer thou doeſt any thinge be well aduiſed.

div.head: Couetouſneſſe, looke liberalitie.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 10. 9. THere is nothing worſe then a couetous man. There is not a more wicked thing then to loue mony, & why? ſuch one hath his ſoule to ſell, yet is he but filthy dounge while he liueth.
Eccleſiaſticus 14. 9. A couetous mans eie hath neuer enough in the porcion of wickedneſſe, vntill the tyme that he wither away, and hath loſt his owne ſoule.
Eccleſiaſticus 14. 3. It becommeth not a couetous man and a nyggard to be rich: & what ſhould a nyggard doe with gold.
Eccleſiaſticus 14. 4. He that with all his carefulnes heapeth togither vnrighteouſly, gathereth for other folkes, and an other man ſhall make good cheere with his goodes.
10. A nigard hath a wicked eye, he turneth away his face, and deſpiſeth his own ſoule.

div.head: Curioſitie.
div.p: Pro. 25. 27. LIke as it is not good to eate to much hony, euen ſo he that will ſearch out hie things it ſhall be to heauy for him.

Eccleſiaſticus 3. 22. 23. 24. 25. Seeke not out the things that are aboue thy capacitie, and ſearch not the ground of ſuch thinges as are to mighty for thee, but looke what God hath commaunded thee, thinke vpon that alway, and be not curious in many of his workes: for it is not needefull for thee to ſee with thine eyes the thinges that are ſecret. Make not thou to much ſearch in ſuperfluous things, and be not curious in many of his works: for many thinges are ſhewed vnto the already, which be aboue the capacitie of men, the medling with ſuch hath begiled many a man, & tangled their witts in vanitie.

div.head: Daughter.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 22. 4. 5. A Wiſe daughter is an heritage vnto her huſband: but ſhe that commeth to diſhoneſtie, bringeth her father in heauineſſe. A daughter that is paſt ſhame diſhonoureth both her father and her huſband, the vngodly ſhall regard her, but they both ſhall deſpiſe her.

Eccleſiaſticus 26. 10. 11. 12. If thy daughter be not ſhamefaſt, holde her ſtraitly, leſt ſhe abuſe her ſelfe through ouer much libertie, beware of all the diſhoneſtie of her eyes: and maruell not if ſhe doe againſt thee: like as one that goeth by the way and is thirſtie, ſo ſhall ſhe open her mouth and drinke of euery next water that ſhe may get. By euery hedge ſhall ſhe ſitte downe, and open her quiuer againſt euery arrow.

Eccleſiaſticus 42. 9. 10 The daughter maketh the father to watch ſecretely: and the carefulnes that he hath for her, taketh away his ſleepe: yea in the youth, leſt ſhe ſhould ouergrow him, & when ſhe hath an huſband, leſt ſhe ſhould be hated: leſt ſhe ſhould be defiled in her virginitie, or gotten with childe in her fathers houſe, or (when ſhe commeth to the man) leſt ſhe behaue her ſelfe not right, or continue vnfruitefull.

Eccleſiaſticus 42. 11. If thy daughter be wanton, keepe her ſtraitly, leſt ſhe cauſe thine enemies to laugh thee to ſcorne, and the whole citie to geue thee an euill report, and ſo thou be faine to heare thy ſhame of euery man, and be confounded before all the people.

div.head: Death.
div.p: Eccleſiaſtes 7. 1. I Iudged thoſe that are deade to be moreEccleſiaſtes 4. 2. 3. happy then thoſe that be aliue: yea him that is yet vnborne to be better at eaſe then they both, becauſe he ſeeth not the miſerable works that are done vnder ye ſunne.
The day of death is better then the day of bir • h.

VViſ. 2. 23. God created man to be vndeſtroyed: yea after the image of his owne likeneſſe made he him. Neuertheleſſe thorough enuie of the Deuill came death into the world, and they that holde of his ſide doe as he doth.
VViſ. 3. 1. The ſoules of the righteous are in the hand of God, and the payne of death ſhall not touch them.

Eccleſiaſticus 10. 11. 12. Though the Phiſicion ſhew his help neuer ſo long, yet in concluſion it goeth after this maner, to day a king to morrow dead. For when a man dieth he is the heire of ſerpents, beaſtes and wormes.
Eccleſiaſticus 11. 28. Prayſe no man before his death, for a man ſhall be knowen in his children.
Eccleſiaſticus 14. 14. Worke thou righteouſnes before thy death, for in the hel there is no meat to find.

Eccleſiaſticus 14. 17. All fleſh ſhall fade away like graſſe, and like a flouriſhing leaſe in a greene tree.
Some grow, ſome are caſt downe, euen ſo is the generation of all fleſh and bloud: one commeth to an ende an other is borne.
Eccleſiaſticus 22. 11. Make but litle weping becauſe of the dead: for he is come to reſt, but the life of the foole is worſe then the death.

Eccleſiaſticus 36. 16. 17. 18. 19. 20. 21. My ſonne bring forth thy teares ouer the dead and beginne to mourne, as if thou haddeſt ſuffered great harme thy ſelfe, and then couer his body after a conuenient maner, and deſpiſe not his buriall. Enforce thy ſelfe to wepe, & prouoke thy ſelfe to mourne and make lamentation expediently, & that a day or two, leſt thou be euill ſpoken of, & then comfort thy heauines, for of heauines commeth death, the heauines of the heart breaketh ſtrēgth, take no heauines to heart, driue it away and remember the laſt thinges, forget it not, for there is no turning againe. Thou ſhalt do him no good but hurt thy ſelfe.

Eccleſiaſticus 41. 1. 2. O death, how bitter is the remembrance of thee to a man that ſeeketh reſt and comfort in his ſubſtance and riches. Vnto the man that hath nothing to vexe him, & that hath proſperitie in all things, yea vnto him that yet is able to receaue meate. O death, how acceptable and good is thy iudgement
vnto the needefull, and vnto him whoſe ſtrength fayleth, and that is now in the laſt age, and that all thinges is full of care and fearefulneſſe, vnto him alſo that is in deſpaire, and hath no hope nor pacience.

Eccleſiaſticus 41. 3. 4. Be not thou afraid of death: remember them that haue bene before thee and that come after thee: this is the iudgement of the Lord ouer all fleſh. And why wouldeſt thou be againſt the pleaſure of the higheſt? whether it be ten hundred or a thouſand yeares, death aſketh not how long one hath liued.

div.head: Delicate liuing.
div.p: Prou. 21. 17 HE that hath pleaſure in bankettes ſhal be a poore man: whoſo deliteth in wine and delicates ſhall not be rich.
Pro. 29. 21. He that delicately bringeth vp his ſeruant from a childe ſhall make him his maſter at length.
Eccleſiaſtes 7. 2. It is better to goe into an houſe of mourning, then into a banketting houſe.

div.head: Diet.
div.p:
Eccleſiaſticus 31. 19. 20. O Howe well content is a wiſe man with a litle wine? ſo that in ſleepe thou ſhalt not be ſicke thereof, nor
feele my paine. A ſweete holſom ſleepe ſhal ſuch a one haue and feele no inward greife. He riſeth vp betimes in the morning, and is well at eaſe in him ſelfe. But an vnſaciable eater ſleepeth vnquietly and hath ache and paine of the body.

Eccleſiaſticus 31. 21. If thou feeleſt that thou haſt eaten to much, ariſe, goe thy way, caſt it out of thy ſtomacke, and take thy reſt, and it ſhall eaſe thee, ſo that thou ſhalt bring no ſickneſſe vnto thy body.

Eccleſiaſticus 37. 28. 29. 30. Be not greedy in euery eating, and be not to haſty vpon all meates, for exceſſe of meates bringeth ſickneſſe, and gluttonie commeth at the laſt to an vnmeaſurable heate. Thorough ſurfet haue many a one periſhed: but he that dieteth him ſelfe temperatly prolongeth his life.

div.head: Diſſembling.
div.p: Pro. 10. 32. DIſſembling lippes keepe hatred ſecretly
Prou. 11. 3. The innocent dealing of the iuſt ſhal leade them: but the wickednes of ſuch as diſſemble ſhall be their own deſtruction.
Pro. 11. 9. Thorough the mouth of the diſſembler is his neighbour deſtroyed.

Pro. 11. 13. A diſſembling perſon wil diſcouer priuy
thinges: but he that is of a faithfull heart will keepe counſell.
Pro. 11. 20. The Lorde abhorreth them that be of a fayned heart, but he hath pleaſure in them that be of an vndefiled conuerſation.
Prou. 12. 17 A true mouth is euer conſtant: but a diſſembling tongue is ſoone chaunged.
Pro. 26. 28. A diſſembling tongue hateth one that rebuketh him: and a flattering mouth worketh miſchiefe.
Eccleſiaſticus 19. 25. A wicked man can behaue him ſelfe humbly, and can ducke with his head, and yet is but a deceauer within.

div.head: Doings of men, looke good men.
div.p: Prou. 16. 7. VVHen a mans wayes pleaſe the Lorde, he maketh his very enemies to be his friendes.
Prou. 16. 1. A man deuiſeth a way in his heart, but it is the Lorde that ordereth his goings.
Pro. 16. 17. The path of the righteous is to eſchew euill, and whoſo looketh well to his wayes keepeth his owne ſoule.
Pro. 16. 33. The lottes are caſt into the lappe, but the ordering thereof ſtandeth all in the Lorde.

Pro. 19. 22. It is a mans worſhip to doe good, & better
it is to be a poore man then a diſſembler.
Prou 20. 6. Many ther be that would be called good doers: but where ſhall one finde a true faithfull man.
Pro. 20. 7. Whoſo leadeth a godly and an innocent life is righteous: and happy ſhall his children be whom he leaueth behind him.
Prou. 20. 9. Who can ſay, my heart is cleane, I am innocent from ſinne.
Pro. 20. 24. The Lord ordereth euery mans going: how may a man then vnderſtand his owne way.
Prou. 21. 2. Euery man thinketh his owne way to be right: but the Lord iudgeth the hearts.
Prou. 21. 3. To doe righteouſnes and iudgement is more acceptable to the Lord then ſacrifice.
Pro. 21. 5. The iuſt deliteth in doing the thing that is right: but ouer the workers of wickednes hangeth deſtruction.
Pro. 24. 16. A iuſt man falleth ſeuen times and riſeth vppe againe: but the vngodly fall into wickednes.
Prou. 25. 21 If thine enemie hunger feede him, if he thirſt geue him drink: for ſo ſhalt thou heap coales of fier vpon his head, and the Lorde ſhall reward thee.

Pro. 28. 13. He that hideth his ſinnes ſhall not proſper: but whoſo knowledgeth them & forſaketh
them ſhall haue mercy.
Prou. 28. 14 Well is him that ſtandeth in awe, as for him that hardeneth his heart he ſhall fall into miſcheefe.
Pro. 28. 18. Whoſo leadeth a godly and an innocent life ſhal be ſaued: but he that goeth froward wayes ſhall once haue a fall.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 7. Iuſtifie not thy ſelfe before God, for he knoweth thy heart, and deſire not to be reputed wiſe in the preſence of the King.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 36. Whatſoeuer thou takeſt in hande, remember the ende and thou ſhalt neuer doe amiſſe.

div.head: Dreames.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 34. 1. VNwiſe people begyle them ſelues with vaine and deceitfull hope, and fooles truſt dreames.
2.Whoſo regardeth dreames is like him that will take holde of a ſhadow and follow after the winde: 3. euen ſo is it with the appearings of dreames.

Eccleſiaſticus 34. 5. 6. Southſaying, witchcraft, ſorcerie and dreaming is but vanitie: like as when a woman trauaileth with childe, & hath many fantaſies in her heart. Where as ſuch viſions come not of God, ſet not thine heart vpon them.

div.head: Drunkenneſſe, looke more in vvine.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 19. 1. A Labouring man that is geuen vnto drunkenneſſe ſhall not be rich, and he that maketh not much of ſmall thinges, ſhall fall by litle and litle.
Eccleſiaſticus 31. 25. 26. Be not thou a wine bibber, for wine hath deſtroyed many a man. The fire proueth the hard iron, euen ſo doth wine proue the heartes of the proude when they be drunken.
Eccleſiaſticus 31. 30. Drunkenneſſe filleth the minde of the fooliſh with ſhame and ruine, miniſheth the ſtrength and maketh woundes.

div.head: Enemie, looke more in loue and euill vvill.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 12. 10. 11. 12. 13. TRuſt neuer thine enemie: For like as iron ruſteth, ſo doth his wickednes, & though he make much crowching and kneeling, yet keepe well thy minde, and beware of him. Sette him not by thee, neither let him ſitte at thy right hande, leſt he turne him, get thee into thy place, take thy roome, and ſeke thy ſeate, and ſo thou at the laſt ſhalt remember my wordes, and be pricked at my ſayinges.

18. An enemie is ſweete in his lippes, heEccleſiaſticus 12. 17. can make many good wordes, and ſpeake many good thinges, yea he can weepe with his eyes, but in his heart he imagineth howe to throwe thee into the pitt: and if he may finde opportunitie, he will not be ſatisfied with bloud. If aduerſitie come vppon thee thou ſhalt finde him there firſt, and though he pretende to doe thee helpe, yet ſhall he vndermyne thee. He ſhall ſhake his heade and clappe his handes ouer thee for very gladneſſe, and while he maketh many wordes he ſhall diſguiſe his countenaunce.

div.head: Father and mother.
div.p: Pro. 17. 21. HE that begetteth a foole, begetteth his ſorrow: and the father of a foole can haue no ioy.
Prou. 19. 18 Chaſten thy ſonne while there is hope: but let not thy ſoule be moued to ſlaye him.
Prou. 22. 6. Teach a childe in his youth what way he ſhould goe: for he ſhall not leaue it when he is olde.
Pro. 23. 24. A righteous father is maruelous glad of a wiſe ſonne: and he that begetteth a wiſe childe, ſhall haue great pleaſure of him.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 23. If thou haue ſonnes, bring them vp in nourtour and learning, and holde them in awe from their youth vp.

Eccleſiaſticus 7. 24. 25. If thou haue daughters, keepe their body and ſhewe not thy face cherefull toward them. Mary thy daughter, and ſo ſhalt thou perfourme a weighty matter, but geue her to a man of vnderſtanding.

Eccleſiaſticus 16. 1. 2. 3. Delite not thou in the multitude of vngodly children: and haue no pleaſure in them if they feare not God. Truſt not thou to their life and regard not their labours. For one ſonne that feareth God, is better then a thouſand vngodly. And better is it for a man to die without children, then to leaue behinde him ſuch children as are vngodly.

Eccleſiaſticus 30. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. Whoſo loueth his child holdeth him ſtil vnder correction, that he may haue ioy of him afterward, and that he grope not after his neighbours dores. He that teacheth his ſonne ſhall haue ioy in him, and neede not to be aſhamed of him among his acquaintāce. Whoſo enformeth and teacheth his ſonne, greeueth the enemie, and before his friends he may ioy of him, though the father dye, yet is he as though he were not dead, for he hath left one behinde him that is like him in
his life, he ſawe him and had ioy in him, and was not ſory in his death, neither was he aſhamed before his enemies, for he left behinde him an auenger againſt his enemies, and a good doer vnto the friendes.
7. He that chaſteneth his childe bindeth the wounds togither, that his heart may feare euery word.
8. An vntamed horſe will be hard, and awanton childe will be wilfull.

Eccleſiaſticus 30. 9. 10. 11. 12. 13. If thou bring vp thy ſonne delicately, he ſhall make thee afraid: & if thou play with him he ſhall bring thee to heauines. Laugh not with him leſt thou wepe with him alſo, and leſt thy teeth be ſet on edge at the laſt. Geue him no libertie in his youth, and excuſe not his folly, bowe downe his necke while he is yong, hit him vpon the ſides, while he is yet but a childe, leſt he waxe ſtubburne and geue no more force of thee, and ſo ſhalt thou haue heauines of ſoule. Teach thy childe and be diligent therein, leſt it be to thy ſhame.

div.head: Feare of the Lord.
div.p: Eccleſiaſticus 1. 15. 16. 17. THe feare of the Lorde is the beginning of wiſedom.

The feare of the lord is the right
ſeruice of God that preſerueth and iuſtifieth the heart and geueth mirth & gladneſſe.
18. Whoſo feareth the Lorde ſhall be happy, and when he hath neede of comfort he ſhall be bleſſed.
20. The feare of the Lord is wiſedom that maketh rich & bringeth all good with her.
22. The feare of the Lorde is the crowne of wiſedom, and geueth plenteous peace and health.
24. The feare of the Lorde is the roote of wiſedom, and her braunches are long life.
26. The feare of the Lord driueth out ſinne: for he that is without feare can not be made righteous, and his wilfull boldneſſe is his owne deſtruction.
Eccleſiaſticus 2. 9. O ye that feare the Lord take ſure hold of his mercy, ſhrinke not away from him, that ye fall not.
10. O ye that feare the Lorde beleue him and your reward ſhall not be empty.
O ye that feare the Lord put your truſt in him: and mercy ſhall come vnto you for pleaſure.
O ye that feare the Lorde ſet your loue vpon him, and your hearts ſhal be lightned.

11. Conſider the olde generations of men, o ye children & marke them well: was there
euer any confounded that put his truſt in the Lord? Who euer continued in his feare12. and was forſaken? Or whom did he euer deſpiſe that called faith fully vpon him? for God is gracious and mercifull, he forgetteth ſinnes in ye time of trouble, & is a defender of all them that ſeeke him in the truth.
16. They that feare the Lorde will not miſtruſt his word, and they that loue him will keepe his commaundements.
17. They that feare the Lord will ſeeke out the things that are pleaſaunt vnto him, and they that loue him will fulfill his lawe.
18. They that feare the Lord will prepare their hearts and humble their ſoules in his ſight.

19. They that feare the lord keepe his commaundements and will be pacient till they ſee him ſelfe, ſaying: better it is for vs to fal into the handes of the Lorde, then into the handes of men:21. for his mercy is as great as him ſelfe.

div.head: Folly.
div.p: Prou. 1. 32. THe proſperitie of fooles ſhalbe their owne deſtruction.

Prou 2. 21. The wiſe ſhal haue honour in poſſeſſion, but ſhame is the promotion yt fooles
ſhall haue.
Pro. 10. 23. A foole doth wickedly and maketh but a ſporte of it: but wiſedom ruleth the man that hath vnderſtanding.
Pro. 12. 16. He that hath vnderſtanding doth hyde wiſedom, but an vndiſcrete foole telleth out his fooliſhnes.
Prou. 14. 7. See that thou medle not with a foole in whom thou perceaueſt to be no knowledge.
Prou. 14. 8. The wiſedom of him that hath vnderſtanding, is to take heede vnto his wayes, but the fooliſhnes of the vnwiſe deceiueth.
Prou. 14 9. Fooles make but a ſporte of ſinne, but there is a fauourable loue among the righteous.
Prou. 18. 7. A fooles mouth is his owne deſtruction, and his lippes are the ſnare of his owne ſoule.
Prou. 26. 3. Vnto the horſe belongeth a whip, to the aſſe a bridle, and a rodde to the fooles back.
Prou. 26. 12 If thou ſeeſt a man that is wiſe in his owne conceit, there is more hope of a foole then in him.
Pro. 26. 17. Whoſo goeth by and medleth with other mens ſtrife, he is like one that taketh a dog by the eares.

Pro. 28. 26. He that truſteth in his owne heart is a foole: but he that dealeth wiſely ſhall be
ſafe.
Eccleſiaſtes 10. 11. The wordes of a wiſe mans mouth are gracious: but the lippes of a foole will deſtroy him ſelfe.
The beginning of his talking is fooliſhneſſe, and laſt word of his mouth is ſtarke madneſſe.
Eccleſiaſticus 21. 14. The heart of a foole is like a broken veſſell, he can keepe no wiſedom.
Eccleſiaſticus 22. 13. Talke not much with a foole, and go not with him that hath no vnderſtanding.
Eccleſiaſticus 27. 13. The talking of fooles is abomination, and their ſporte is voluptuouſneſſe and miſnurtour.

div.head: Fortune commonly called in deede nothing elſe but the prouidence of God.
div.p: Eccleſiaſtes 4. 14. SOme one commeth out of priſon and is made a King: and an other which is borne in the kingdom commeth vnto pouertie.

Eccleſiaſtes 9. 10. In running it helpeth not to be ſwift, in battayle it helpeth not to be ſtrong: to feeding it helpeth not to be wiſe: to richeſſe it helpeth not to be ſubtil: to be had in fauour it helpeth not to be cunning, but that all lieth in time and fortune.
Eccleſiaſticus 11. 5. Many tyrauntes haue bene faine to ſitte downe vpon the earth, and the vnlikly haue worne the crowne.
Eccleſiaſticus 11. 6. Many mighty men haue bene brought lowe: and the honorable haue bene deliuered into other mens handes.

Eccleſiaſticus 11. 11. 12. There is ſome man that laboureth, and the more he werieth him ſelfe, the leſſe he hath. Againe ſome man is ſlouthfull, hath nede of help, wanteth ſtrength & hath great pouertie, and Gods eye loketh vpon him to good, ſetteth him from his low eſtate, & lifteth vp his head: ſo that many men maruell at him and geue honour vnto God.

Eccleſiaſticus 11. 21. Continue not in the workes of ſinners, but put thy truſt in God, and bide in thine eſtate: for it is but an eaſy thing in the ſight of God to make a poore man rich, and that ſodenly.
Eccleſiaſticus 20. 9. Some man getteth a fall for being to proude, and ſome commeth to worſhip from low eſtate.

Eccleſiaſticus 37. 18. 19. 20. 21. Some man is apt and well enſtructed in many things, and yet very vnprofitable vnto him ſelfe. Some man there is that can geue wiſe and prudent counſell, and yet is he hated, and continueth a beggar: for the grace is not geuen him of God to be accepted.
An other is robbed of all wiſedome, yet is he wiſe vnto him ſelfe, and the fruit of vnderſtanding is commendable in his mouth.

div.head: Friendſhip.
div.p: Prou. 17. 17 HE is a friend that alway loueth, and in aduerſitie a man ſhall know who is his brother.
Prou. 18. 19 A brother though he be greeued with offence, yet is he more worth then a very ſtrong caſtell: and they that holde togither are like the barre of a pallace.
Pro. 18. 24. A man that loueth his friendes will be companable with them: and ſome friende ſticketh faſter to a man then his brother.
Prou. 27. 6. Faythfull are the woundes of a louer, but the kiſſes of an enemy are cruell.
Prou. 27. 9. Balme & ſweete incenſe make the heart merry: ſo is the ſweete counſell of a mans friende that agreeth to his purpoſe.
Pro. 27. 10. Thine own friend and thy fathers friend ſee thou forſake not: but goe not into thy brothers houſe in time of trouble, for better is a friende at hande then a brother a farre of.

Eccleſiaſtes 4. 9. 10. 11. 12. Two are better then one, for they may well enioye the profite of their labour. For if one of them fall, his companion
helpeth him vp againe: But woe is him that is alone: for if he fall he hath not an other to helpe him vppe. Againe, when two ſleepe togither they are warme, but howe can a body be warme alone? one may be ouercome, but two may make reſiſtance. A threefold gable is not lightly broken.
Eccleſiaſticus 6. 6. Holde friendſhip with many, neuertheleſſe haue but one counſeller of a thouſand.

Eccleſiaſticus 6. 7 8. 9. 10. 11. 12 If thou getteſt a friend proue him firſt, and be not haſty to geue him credence, for ſome man is a friend but for a time, & will not abide in the day of trouble. And there is ſome friend that turneth to enmitie, and taketh part againſt thee, and if he knowe any hurt by thee he telleth it out. Againe ſome friend is but a companion at the table, and in the day of neede he continueth not. But a ſure friend will be vnto thee euen as thine owne ſelfe, and deale faithfully with thy houſhold folke. If thou ſuffer trouble and aduerſitie he is with thee.
Eccleſiaſticus 6. 13. Depart from thyne enemies, yea and beware of thy friendes.

Eccleſiaſticus 6. 14. 15. 16. 17. A faithfull friende is a ſtronge defence, whoſo findeth ſuch one findeth a treaſure. A faithfull friend hath no peare, the weight of golde and ſiluer is not to be compared to
the goodnes of his faith. A faithfull friende is a medicine of life, and they that feare the Lorde ſhall finde him. Whoſo feareth the Lorde ſhall proſper with friendes, and as he is him ſelfe ſo ſhall his friend be alſo.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 18. Geue not ouer thy friend for any good, nor thy faithfull brother for the beſt golde.
Eccleſiaſticus 9. 12. Forſake not an olde friend, for the newe ſhall not be like him. A newe friend is new wine: let him be olde and thou ſhalt drinke him with pleaſure.
Eccleſiaſticus 19. 15. Tell thy friend his fault leſt he be ignoraunt, and ſay: I haue not done it, or if he haue ſpoken that he doe it no more.

Eccleſiaſticus 27. 17. 18. Loue thy friend and binde thy ſelfe in faithfulnes with him, but if thou bewrayeſt his ſecretes thou ſhalt not get him againe: For like as the man is that deſtroyeth his enemie, ſo is he alſo that dealeth falſely in the friendſhip of his neighbour.
Eccleſiaſticus 37. 4. There is ſome companion which in proſperitie reioyceth with his friend: but in the time of trouble he taketh part againſt him.

div.head: Giftes or revvardes.
div.p: Prou. 17. 8. A Reward is a precious ſtone vnto him that hath, 〈◊〉 but vnto whomſoeuer it turneth, it maketh him vnwiſe.
Pro. 17. 13. Whoſo rewardeth euill for good, the plague ſhall not depart from his houſe.
Pro. 17. 23. The vngodly taketh gifts out of the boſome to wreſt the waies of iudgement.
Prou. 19. 6. The multitude hangeth vpon great men: and euery man fauoureth him that geueth rewardes.
Prou. 21. 14 A priuy rewarde pacifieth diſpleaſure, & a gift in the boſome ſtilleth furiouſneſſe.
Pro. 25. 13. Whoſo maketh great boaſtes and geueth nothing, is like cloudes & winde without raine.

div.head: God.
div.p: Prou. 3. 5. 6 7. PUt thy truſt in God with all thine hearte, and leane not vnto thyne owne witte: in all thy wayes haue reſpect vnto him, and he ſhall order thy goinges. Be not wiſe in thine owne conceite, but feare the Lorde and depart from euill.
Prou. 5. 21. Euery mans wayes are open in the ſight of the Lorde, and he pondereth all their goings.
Prou. 15. 3. The eyes of the Lorde looke on euery place beholding both the good and badde.

Pro. 15. 11. The hell with her paine is knowen vnto
ye lord: how much more then ye hearts of mē?
Prou. 16. 1. 2. 3. A man may well purpoſe a thing in his heart, but the anſwere of the tongue commeth of the Lord.
A man thinketh all his wayes to be cleane, but it is the Lorde that iudgeth the minde. Commit thy workes vnto the Lord and loke what thou deuiſeſt it ſhall proſper.
Pro. 20. 22. Say not thou I will recompence euill: but put thy truſt in the Lorde and he ſhall defend thee.
Pro. 29. 25. He that feareth men ſhall haue a fall: but whoſo putteth his truſt in the Lord is without daunger.

Eccleſiaſtes 8. 12. Though an euill perſon offend an hundred times, & God defer, geuing him long life: yet am I ſure that it ſhall goe wel with them that feare God, becauſe they haue him before their eyes.
Eccleſiaſtes 12. 13. Feare God and keepe his commaundements, for that toucheth all men, for God ſhall iudge all workes, and ſecrete thinges whether they be good or euill.
Eccleſiaſticus 13. 8. Eccleſiaſticus 13. 13. Eccleſiaſticus 15. 11. 12. 13. Submit thy ſelfe vnto God and waite vpon his hande.
Loue God all thy life long, and call vpon him in thy neede.

Say not thou, it is the Lordes fault that
I am gone by, for thou ſhalt not doe the thing that God hateth. Say not thou, he hath cauſed me to doe wronge, for he hath no neede of the vngodly. God hateth all abomination of errour, and they that feare God will loue none ſuch.

Eccleſiaſticus 16. 11. 12. Mercy and wrath is with him: he is both mighty to forgeue, & to poure out diſpleaſure: like as his mercy is greate, euen ſo is his puniſhment alſo, he iudgeth a man according to his workes.

Eccleſiaſticus 32. 23. 24. In all thy workes put thy truſt in God from thy whole heart, for that is the keping of the commaundements: whoſo beleueth Gods word taketh heede to the commaundements, and he that putteth his truſt in the Lord ſhall want nothing.
Eccleſiaſticus 33. 1. There ſhall no euill happen vnto him that feareth God: but when he is in tentation, the Lorde ſhall deliuer him and keepe him from euill.

Eccleſiaſticus 33. 12. Like as the clay is in the potters hand, and all the ordering thereof at his pleaſure: ſo are men alſo in the handes of him that made them, ſo that he may geue them as liketh him beſt.

div.head: Good men and euill.
div.p: Prou. 2. 21. 22. THe iuſt ſhall dwell in the lande, and they that be perfect ſhall remaine in it: but the vngodly ſhall be rooted out of the lande and the wicked doers ſhall be rooted out of it.
Prou. 3. 33. The curſe of the Lord is in the houſe of the vngodly: but he bleſſeth the dwellings of the righteous.
Prou. 3. 31. 32. Followe not a wicked man and chooſe none of his wayes: for the Lord abhorreth the froward, but his counſell is among the righteous.

Prou. 4. 14. 15. 16. Come not in the path of the vngodly, and walk not in the way of the wicked, abhorre it and goe not therin, depart aſide and paſſe ouer by it: for they can not ſlepe except they haue firſt done ſome miſchief: neither take they any reſt except they haue firſt done ſome harme.

Prou. 4. 18. 19. The path of the rightwiſe ſhineth as the light, that is euer brighter and brighter vnto the perfect day: but the way of the vngodly is as the darkeneſſe, they knowe not where they fall.
Prou. 10. 16 The righteous laboureth to doe good: but the vngodly vſeth his encreaſe vnto ſin.

Pro. 10. 25. The vngodly paſſeth when the tempeſt commeth: but the righteous remaineth
ſure for euer.
Pro. 10. 30. The righteous ſhall neuer be ouerthrowen: but the vngodly ſhall not remaine in the land.
Prou. 11. 6. The righteouſneſſe of the iuſt ſhall deliuer them: but the wicked ſhall be taken in their owne vngodlineſſe.
Pro. 11. 18. The labour of the vngodly proſpereth not: but he that ſoweth righteouſnes ſhall receaue a ſure rewarde.
Pro. 11. 19. Like as righteouſneſſe bringeth life, euen ſo to cleaue vnto euill bringeth death.
Prou. 12. 7. God ouerturneth the eſtate of the wicked and they ſtand not: but the houſe of the righteous ſhall ſtand ſtedfaſt.
Pro. 12. 21. There ſhall no misfortune happen vnto the iuſt, but the vngodly ſhall be filled with miſerie.
Prou. 13. 21 Miſchiefe followeth vppon ſinners, but the righteous ſhall haue a good reward.
Pro. 14. 11. The houſe of the vngodly ſhall be ouerthrowen: but the tabernacle of the righteous ſhall flouriſh.
Prou. 15. 9. The way of the vngodly is an abomination vnto the Lorde: but whoſo followeth righteouſnes, him he loueth.
Pro. 15. 29. The Lord is farre from the vngodly, but he heareth the prayer of the righteous.

VViſ. 5. 16. 17. The righteous ſhall liue for euermore, their rewarde alſo is with the Lorde, and their remembrance with the higheſt. Therfore ſhall they receaue a glorious kingedom, and a bewtifull crowne at the Lordes hand: for with his right hand ſhall he couer them, and with his owne holy arme ſhall he defend them.

Eccleſiaſticus 40. 9. 10 Death, bloudſheding, ſtrife, and ſworde, oppreſſion, hunger, deſtruction, and puniſhment, theſe thinges are created againſt the vngodly, and for their ſakes came the floud alſo.

div.head: Health and ſickneſſe.
div.p: Pro. 18. 14. A Good ſtomack driueth away a mans diſeaſe, but when the ſpirite is vexed who may abide it?

Eccleſiaſticus 30. 14. 15. 16. Better is the pore being whole & ſtrong, then a man to be rich and not to haue his health. Health & welfare is aboue all gold, and a whole body aboue all treaſure. There is no riches aboue a ſound body, and no ioy aboue the ioy of the heart. Death is better then a wretched life, and eternall reſt better then continuall ſickneſſe.

div.head: Hovvſe and huſbandry.
div.p: Pro. 24. 27. FIrſt make vp thy worke that is without, and looke well vnto that which thou haſt in the fielde, and then builde thine houſe.
Pro. 24. 3. 4 Thorough wiſedome is an houſe builded, and with vnderſtanding is it ſett vppe. Thorough diſcretion ſhal the chambers be filled with all coſtly and pleaſant riches.
Pro. 27. 23. See that thou knowe the number of thy cattell thy ſelf, and looke well to thy flocks: for riches abide not alway, and the crowne endureth not for euer.
Pro. 27. 25. The hay groweth, the graſſe commeth vp, and herbes are gathered in the mountaines.

Pro. 27. 26. The lambes ſhall cloth thee, and for thy goates thou ſhalt haue money to thy huſbandry: thou ſhalt haue goates milke enough to feede thee, to vphold thy houſhold and to ſuſtaine thy maidens.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 15. Let no laborious worke be tedious vnto thee, neither the huſbandry which the Almighty hath created.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 22. If thou haue cattell looke well to them, and if they be for thy profite, keepe them.
Eccleſiaſtes 48. The encreaſe of the earth vpholdeth all thing: yea the King him ſelfe is maintayned by huſbandry.

div.head: Houſevvife.
div.p:
Pro. 31. 10. ad finem. WHoſo findeth an honeſt faithfull woman, ſhe is much more worth then pearles. The heart of her huſband may ſafely truſt in her, ſo that he ſhall fall in no pouertie. She will doe him good, and not euill all the dayes of her life. She occupieth woll and flaxe, and laboureth gladly with her handes. She is like a marchaunts ſhip that bringeth her vittails from farre. She is vp in the night ſeaſon to prouide meate for her houſhold, and foode for her maidens. She conſidereth land and byeth it, and with the fruite of her handes ſhe planteth a vineyarde. She girdeth her loynes with ſtrength, and courageth her armes. And if ſhe perceaue that her houſewifery doth good, her candell goeth not out by night. She laieth her fingers to the ſpindle, and her hand taketh hold of the diſtaffe. She openeth her hand to the poore, yea ſhe ſtretcheth forth her handes to ſuch as haue neede. She feareth not that the cold of winter ſhall hurt her houſe, for all her houſhold folke are clothed with ſcarlet. She maketh her ſelfe fine ornamentes, her clothing is white ſilke and purple. Her huſband is
much ſet by in the gates. When he ſitteth among the rulers of the lande. She maketh cloth of ſilke and ſelleth it, and deliuereth girdles vnto the marchaunt. Strength and honour is her clothing, and in the latter daye ſhe ſhall reioyce. She openeth her mouth with wiſedom, and in her tongue is the lawe of grace. She looketh well to the wayes of her houſholde, and eateth not her breade with idleneſſe. Her children ſhall ariſe and call her bleſſed, and her huſband ſhall make much of her. Many daughters there be that gather riches togither, but thou goeſt aboue them all. As for fauour it is deceitfull, and bewtie is a vayne thinge. But a woman that feareth the Lorde, ſhe is worthy to be prayſed. Geue her of the fruite of her hands, and let her owne works prayſe her in the gates.

div.head: Iudge and iudgement.
div.p: Pro. 17. 15. THe Lord hateth as well him that iuſtifieth the vngodly as him that condemneth the innocent.
Prou. 18. 5. It is not good to regard the perſon of the vngodly, or to put backe the righteous in iudgement.

Pro. 18. 13. He that geueth ſentence in a matter before
he heare it, is a foole and worthy to be confounded.

Pro. 22. 22. See that thou robbe not the poore becauſe he is weake, and oppreſſe not the ſimple in iudgement, for the Lorde him ſelfe will defende their cauſe, and doe violence vnto them that haue vſed violence.
Pro. 24. 11. Deliuer them that goe vnto death, and are ledde away to be ſlayne, and be not negligent therein: if thou be able to doe them good.

Pro. 24. 23. 24. 25. It is not good to haue reſpect of any perſon in iudgement. He that ſayeth to the vngodly thou art righteous, him ſhal the people curſe: yea the comminaltie ſhall abhorre him. But they that rebuke the vngodly, in them doth God delite, and a rich bleſſing ſhall come vppon them.
Prou. 29. 7. The righteous conſidereth the cauſe of the poore, but the vngodly regardeth no vnderſtanding.

Prou. 31. 8. 9. Be thou aduocate for the dumme, and ſtand in iudgement thy ſelfe to ſpeake for all ſuch as be ſuccourleſſe in this tranſitory worlde. Open thy mouth, defende the thing that is lawfull and right, and the cauſe of the poore and helpeleſſe.

Eccleſiaſtes 3. 16. 17. I ſawe vnder the Sunne vngodlines in the ſtede of iudgment, and iniquitie in ſtede of righteouſneſſe. Then I thought in my minde: God ſhall ſeparate the righteous from the vngodly, and then ſhall be the time and iudgement of all counſell and workes.

Eccleſiaſtes 5. 7. If thou ſeeſt the poore to be oppreſſed and wrongfully dealt withall, ſo that equity and the right of the law is wreſted in the lande, maruell not thou at ſuch a thing: for one great man kepeth touch with an other, and the mighty men are in authoritie ouer the poore.
Eccleſiaſtes 5. 5. VViſ. 1. 1. 2 See that thou iuſtifie the ſmal and great alike.

O ſet your affection vpon righteouſnes, ye that be iudges of the earth. Haue a good opinion of the Lorde, and ſeeke him in the ſingleneſſe of heart, for he will be founde of them that tempt him not, and appeareth vnto ſuch as put their truſt in him.

VViſ. 6. 2. 3 4. 5. 6. 7. O learne ye that be iudges of the earth. Geue eare ye that rule the multitudes, and delite in much people. For the power is geuen you of the Lorde, and the ſtrength from the higheſt: which ſhall trie your workes, and ſerch out your imaginations. How that ye being officers of his kingdom, haue not
executed true iudgement: haue not kept the 〈◊〉 righteouſnes: nor walked after the 〈◊〉 of God. Horrible and that right ſoone 〈◊〉 appeare vnto you: for an hard iudgment 〈◊〉 they haue that bare rule. Mercy is graunted vnto the ſimple, but they that be 〈◊〉 authoritie ſhall be ſore puniſhed.

Eccleſiaſticus 4. 9. 10. Deliuer him that ſuffereth wrong from the hand of the oppreſſour, and be not faynt hearted when thou ſitteſt in iudgement. Be mercifull vnto the fatherleſſe as a father, and be 〈◊〉 of an huſband vnto their mother, ſo ſhalt thou be as an obedier • ſonne of the higheſt, and he ſhall loue thee more then thy mother doth.
Eccleſiaſticus 10. 1. A wiſe iudge will order his people with diſcretion: and where a man of vnderſtanding beareth rule, there goeth it well.
Eccleſiaſticus 10. 2. 3. As the iudge of the people is him ſelfe, euen ſo are his officers: and looke what maner of man the ruler of the citie is, ſuch are they that dwell therein alſo.
Eccleſiaſticus 10. 21. Greate is the iudge and mighty in honour, yet is there none greater then he that feareth God.

Eccleſiaſticus 11. 7. 8. Condemne no man before thou haue tried out the matter, and when thou haſt made inquiſition, then reforme righteouſly. Geue
no ſentence before thou haſt hearde the cauſe, but firſt let men tell out their tales.

div.head: Knovvledge and learning.
div.p: Prou. 1. 5. BY hearing the wiſe, man ſhall come by more wiſedom.

Pro. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. If thou cryeſt after wiſedom, and calleſt for knowledge: If thou ſeekeſt after her as after money, and diggeſt for her as for treaſure, then ſhalt thou vnderſtand the feare of the Lord, and finde the knowledge of God: For it is the Lorde that geueth wiſedom, out of his mouth commeth knowledge and vnderſtanding.
Prou. 2. 10. 11. If wiſedom enter into thyne heart and thy ſoule delite in knowledge, then ſhal coū ſell preſerue thee, and vnderſtanding ſhall keepe thee.
Pro. 10. 13. In the lipps of him that hath vnderſtanding a man ſhall finde wiſedom.
Pro. 14. 15. An ignoraunt body beleueth all things: but whoſo hath vnderſtanding looketh well to his goings.
Pro. 18. 15. A wiſe heart laboureth for knowledge, and a prudent eare ſeeketh vnderſtanding.

Pro. 22. 17. 18. My ſonne bowe downe thine eare, & harken vnto the words of wiſedom: apply thy mind vnto my doctrine, for thou ſhalt be excellent
if thou keepe it in thy heart, & practiſe it in thy mouth that thou maiſt put thy truſt in the Lord.
Eccleſiaſtes 1. 18. Where much wiſedom is, there is alſo great trauell and diſquietnes, and the more knowledge a mā hath, the more is his care.
Eccleſiaſtes 1. 8. All things are ſo hard to be knowen that no man can expreſſe them.
Eccleſiaſtes 3. 11. God hath planted ignoraunce alſo in the hearts of men, that they ſhould not comprehend the grounde of his workes which he doth from the beginning to the ende.
Eccleſiaſticus 20. 29. Wiſedom that is hid, & treaſure that is horded vp, what profit is in them both? Better is he that kepeth his ignoraunce ſecret, then a man that hideth his wiſedom.
Eccleſiaſticus 21. 21. Learning is vnto a wiſe man a iewell of golde, and like an armelet vpon his right arme.
Eccleſiaſticus 21. 13. The knowledge of the wiſe ſhall flowe like water that runneth ouer, and his counſell is like a fountaine of life.

div.head: King or Prince.
div.p: Pro. 14. 28. THe encreaſe and proſperitie of the commons is the Kings honour: but the decay of the people is the confuſion of the Prince.
Pro. 16. 10 When the prophecie is in the lippes of the King, his mouth ſhall not goe wrong in iudgement.
Pro. 16. 12. It is a great abomination when Kings are wicked, for a Kings ſeate ſhould be holden vp with righteouſnes.
Pro. 16. 13. Righteous lippes are pleaſaunt vnto Kings, and he that ſpeaketh the truth ſhall be beleued.
Prou. 16. 14 The Kings diſpleaſure is a meſſenger of death: but a wiſe man will pacifie him.
Pro. 16. 15. The cherefull countenaunce of the king is life: and his louing fauour is as the euening dewe.
Prou. 17. 7. Speech of authoritie becommeth not a foole: much leſſe a lying mouth then beſemeth a Prince.
Pro. 19. 12. The Kings disfauour is like the roring of a lyon: but his friendſhip is like the dew vpon the graſſe.
Prou. 20. 2. The King ought to be feared as the roring of a lyon: Whoſo prouoketh him to anger offendeth againſt his owne ſoule.
Prou. 20. 8. A King that ſitteth in the throne of iudgment, and looketh well about him, driueth away all euill.
Pro. 20. 26. A wiſe Kinge deſtroyeth the vngodly, and bringeth the wheele ouer them.
Pro. 20. 28. Mercy and faithfulneſſe preſerue the King: and with louing kindneſſe his ſeate is holden vp.
Prou. 21. 1. The Kinges heart is in the hande of the Lorde, like as are the riuers of water, he may turne it whither ſo euer he will.

Pro. 24. 21. 22. My ſonne, feare thou the Lorde and the Kinge, and keepe no company with them that ſlide backe from his feare: for their deſtruction ſhal come ſodenly, and who knoweth the aduerſity that may come from them both.
Prou 25. 1. It is the honour of God to kepe a thing ſecrete, but the Kinges honour is to ſearch out a thing.
Prou. 25. 2. The heauen is high, the earth is deepe, and the Kings heart is vnſearchable.
Prou. 25. 3. 4. Take the droſſe from the ſiluer and there ſhall be a cleane veſſell thereof. Take away vngodlines from the Kinge, and his ſeate ſhall be eſtabliſhed with righteouſnes.
Pro. 28. 15. Like as the roring of a lyon and an hungry beare, euen ſo is an vngodly Prince ouer the poore people.
Pro. 28. 16. Where the prince is without vnderſtanding, there is great oppreſſion & wronge: but if he be ſuch a one as hateth couetouſneſſe, he ſhall long raigne.
Prou. 29. 4. With true iudgement the King ſetteth vp the land: but if he be a man that oppreſſeth the people with gatheringes, he turneth it vpſide downe.
Pro. 29. 14. The ſeat of the King that faithfully iudgeth the poore ſhall continue ſure for euermore.

Prou. 31. 4. It is not for Kinges, it is not (I ſay) for Kings to drinke wine, nor Princes ſtrong drinke: for there is no ſecrete where drunkennes raineth, leſt they being drunken forget the lawe, and peruert the iudgement of all poore mens children.

Eccleſiaſtes 10. 15. 16. Woe be vnto thee (O land) whoſe King is but a child, & whoſe princes are earely at their bankettes. But well is thee (O land) whoſe King is come of nobles, and whoſe Princes eate in due ſeaſon for neceſſitie and not for luſt.

div.head: Labour, looke more in ſlouthfulneſſe.
div.p: Eccleſiaſtes 3. 9. WHat hath a man elſe (that doth any thing) but werines & labour? For as touching the trauell and carefulneſſe which God hath geuen vnto men, I ſee that he hath geuen it them to be exerciſed in it.

Eccleſiaſtes 3. 13. All that a man eateth and drinketh, yea,
whatſoeuer a man enioyeth of all his labour, that ſame is a gift of God.
Eccleſiaſtes 3. 22. I perceaue that there is nothing better for a man then to be ioyfull in his labour: for that is his portion.

div.head: Lavve of God and man.
div.p: Pro. 13. 14. THe law is a wel of life vnto the wiſe, that it may keepe him from ye ſnares of death.

Pro. 25. 7. 8 9. Be not haſty to goe to the lawe, leſt happly thou doe ſome offence after the ſtrife be ended, whereby thy neighbour put thee to ſhame. Handle thy matter with thy neighbour him ſelfe, and diſcouer not an other mans ſecret, leſt when men heare therof, it turn to thy diſhonour, and leſt thine euill name doe not ceaſe.
Prou. 28. 4. They that forſake the law praiſe the vngodly: but ſuch as kepe ye law abhorre them.
Prou. 28. 7. Whoſo keepeth the lawe is a childe of vnderſtanding: but he that is a companion of riotous men ſhameth his father.
Pro. 28. 9. He that turneth away his eare from hearing the lawe, his prayer ſhall be abominable.

Prou. 29. 9. If a wiſe man goe to lawe with a foole, (whether he deale wt him frendly or roughly
he getteth no reſt.
Pro. 29. 18. When the worde of God is not preeched, the people periſh but well is him that keepeth the lawe.

Prou. 30. 5. 6. All the wordes of God are pure and cleane, for he is a ſhield vnto all them that put their truſt in him. Put thou nothing vnto his wordes, leſt he reproue thee and thou be found a liar.
Eccleſiaſticus 6. 38. Let thy minde be vpon the commaundements of God, and be earneſtly occupied in his lawes, ſo ſhall he eſtabliſh thy heart and geue thee wiſedom at thine owne deſire.
Eccleſiaſticus 8. 14. Goe not to lawe with the iudge, for he will iudge according to his owne honour.
Eccleſiaſticus 19. 24. A crafty ſubtell man can be wiſe, but he is vnrighteous, and with giftes he wraſteth the open and manifeſt law.

div.head: Lending and borovving.
div.p:
Eccleſiaſticus 29. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. WHoſo will ſhewe mercy let him lende vnto his neighbour: and he that is able let him keepe the commaundement. Lende vnto thy neighbour in time of his neede, and pay thou thy neighbour againe in due ſeaſon. Keepe thy worde, and deale faithfully with him, and thou ſhalt alway finde the thing that is neceſſary
for thee. There haue ben many that when a thing was lent them, reckened it to be founde, and made them trauaile and labour that had helped them. While they receaue any thing they kiſſe the handes of ſuch as geue them, for their neighboures good they humble their voyce: but when they ſhould pay againe, they keepe it back, and geue euill wordes, and make many excuſes by reaſon of time: and though he be able, yet geueth he ſcarſe the halfe againe, and reckeneth the other to be found. And if he with holde not his money, yet hath he an enemy of him, and that vndeſerued. He payeth him with curſing and rebuke, and geueth him euill wordes for his good deede.

Eccleſiaſticus 29. 7. 8. 9. 10. There be many one which are not glad for to lende, not becauſe of euill, but they feare to leſe the thing that they lende: yet haue thou pacience with the ſimple, & withholde not mercy from him. Helpe the poore for the commaundements ſake, and let him not goe empty from thee becauſe of his neceſſity. Leſe thy money for thy brother and neighboures ſake, and bury it not vnder a ſtone where it ruſteth and corrupteth.

div.head: Liberalitie.
div.p: Prou. 11. 24 SOme man geueth out his goodes and is the richer: but the nigard (hauing enough) wil depart from nothing, and yet is euer in pouertie.
Pro. 11. 25. He that is liberall in geuing ſhall haue plenty: and he that watereth ſhall be watered alſo him ſelfe.
Pro. 11. 26. Whoſo hordeth vp his corne ſhalbe curſed among the people: but bleſſing ſhall light vpon his head that geueth foode.
Pro. 18. 16. Liberalitie bringeth a man to honour & worſhip, and ſetteth him among great men.
Eccleſiaſticus 7. 33. Be liberal vnto al men liuing, yet let not but doe good euen vnto them that are dead.
Eccleſiaſticus 31. 23. Whoſo is liberal in dealing out his meat, many men ſhall bleſſe him, and prayſe him with their lippes, and the ſame is a ſure token of his loue and faithfulneſſe.
Eccleſiaſticus 40. 17. Friendlineſſe and liberalitie is the encreaſe and bleſſing of God, is like a paradiſe and garden of pleaſure: ſuch mercy alſo and kindnes endureth for euer.

div.head: Loue and euill vvill.
div.p: Pro. 10. 12. EVill wil ſtirreth vp ſtrife, but loue couereth the multitude of ſinnes.
Pro. 15. 17. Better is a meſſe of pottage with loue, then a fatte oxe with euill will.

Pro. 23. 6. 7 Eate thou not with the enuious, and deſire not his meate: for he doth as a man that preſcribeth a meaſure to thee in his heart. He ſayeth vnto thee, eate and drinke, where as his heart is not with him.
Pro. 24. 17. 18. Reioyce not thou at the fall of thine enemie, and let not thine heart be glad when he ſtumbleth, leſt the Lorde (when he ſeeth it) be angry and turne his wrath from him vnto thee.
Pro. 26. 23. Venimous lipps and a wicked heart are like a potſhard couered with ſiluer droſſe.
Pro. 26. 24. 25. An enemie ſhall be knowen by his talking, and in the meane ſeaſon he imagineth miſchiefe, but when he ſpeaketh faire beleue him not, for there are ſeuen abominations in his heart.
Pro. 26. 26. Whoſo keepeth euill will ſecretely to doe hurte, his malice ſhall be ſhewed before the whole congregation.
Eccleſiaſticus 8. 7. Be not glad of the death of thine enemy, but remember that we muſt dye all the ſort of vs.

Eccleſiaſticus 25. 1. Three thinges there are that my ſpirite fauoureth, which be alſo allowed before God and man. The vnitie of brethren, the loue of neighbours, a man and wife that agree well togither.
